p: More recently, Falcão et al. (2016) described the antinociceptive action of an ethyl acetate fraction from the leaves of the above-cited species and its main constituent, rosmarinic acid ( 222) (formalin, glutamate and capsaicin induced orofacial nociception in rodents). The results evidenced that the oral administration of the extract produced potent antinociceptive effects when compared with its main constituent. In spite of rosmarinic acid ( 222) be the main component of the tested fraction, the presented action is probably due to an additive or synergism effect among the metabolites extracted with ethyl acetate. Together, these findings ( Lisboa et al., 2006; Arrigoni-Blank et al., 2008; Falcão et al., 2016) support the use of this species in the Brazilian folk medicine to treat headaches, toothaches and liver neuropathic pain ( de Albuquerque et al., 2007).
